Fields.DialogueText: Saguenay, I wonder-
Calice de Crisse!
Whoa! Saguenay, it's me!
Dieu merci. I was not looking forward to washing blood off my deck.
W-what?
Don't sneak up on me like that, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't your motto "A l'erte?"
Sorry. I thought you could sense me coming.
You wouldn't really have attacked me. Right?

Fields.DialogueText: It's going to be "Nurse my capitaine back to health" if you surprise me like that again!
When I am paying attention, oui.
Had I not known it was you... who can say?
Captain! Miss Saguenay! Morganas are... um...
Spit it out, sailor.
Is now a bad time?
Action stations, sailor. We'll be ready.
@BATTLE
R-right!
Now would you kindly remove your knife from my throat?
Ah! Désolée, Capitaine.
Pantoute. Keep walking. I'm not even here.
You're in my way!
I'm walking backwards and matching your pace. Keeps a girl sharp.

Fields.MenuText: Do you want me to give you more work to do?
It keeps a captain nervous.
If you want to look at me, just ask.

Fields.DialogueText: If you can find it. You know I don't sleep.
I'll cure you of that soon enough.
I admit the view is pleasant.
Don't you worry about running into something?
Non. A sufficiently wary Belle knows the location of everyone and everything aboard her, as well as what's going on.
Does she now?
Ask me something. Anything.
Where is... Ensign Schober?
Swabbing the galley.
Current speed.
Holding steady at thirty knots.
How many torpedoes are we carrying?
Enough.
@BATTLE
Saguenay, if you could just step aside-
That's not a real answer.
It'll get us through the impending fight. My Manitou senses are intact even with you distracting me.
I'm not... that's... heh. Well done, Saguenay.
What did you call the Morganas before?
Manitou?
That.
Spirits, essentially.
Ghosts?
Spirits. There's a difference.

Fields.MenuText: Like gods?
What's God have to say about that?
Not evil spirits?

Fields.DialogueText: Small g. The Japanese Belles have something similar in their Shinto.
If pressed I'd describe Him as first among equals, and even that's a matter for debate.
Well, that goes without saying.
But even the fish have spirits of their own. Observe.
Whoa, that's a big one!
Weight is immaterial. I just have to keep the line from... there! Help me hold him, Capitaine! Fais-le au plus sacrant!
Saguenay, that's a shark!
Only a small one! It's a slippery- agh! My knife!
I've got it! Hah!
... Expertly done, Capitaine. How did you know where to stab?
I just kind of... guessed.
Tabarnak! Not a moment too soon. We've got Manitou.
What do we do with the shark?
I'll move it. You go do capitaine things.
@BATTLE
Well, it was a good guess. Straight through the heart. He didn't suffer at all.
... You know it's a he?
Like my decorating, Capitaine?
That's one way to describe the shark skeleton on your smokestack.
My structure will do for a scaffold in absence of wood. This is just until I have the time to burn the bones.

Fields.MenuText: And here I thought we had a new mascot.
What will they tell us?
Hopefully soon. That thing's unnerving.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing so base, Capitaine. The beast must be dignified in death.
We can't be certain. The animal has its own priorities. All we can do is watch and interpret.
I'm sorry you feel that way.
You should be proud, Capitaine. After all, you killed it.
After you wrestled it aboard the ship.
Whereupon I immediately dropped my knife. Such clumsiness is death on the hunt.
Sounds like you're slipping, Saguenay. You sure we're all safe?
Niaiseux. I'm the safest place for hundreds of miles.
Until you blow up a gunnery crew.
I blasted a Manitou in half with that shot! I can't help my sailors' sense of urgency. Or lack thereof.
I suppose they were back on their feet next day. Maybe they'll hear the spirits through the tinnitus.
I'll give you tinnitus. A capitaine should lead by example.
I'll take you up on it. Teach me to hunt like you do and the crew will follow.
Franchement?
Come on. How hard could it be? You taught me your superstitions.
Habit. Memorization. Those are easy. Hunting isn't just about efficiency, Capitaine. It's about respect for your kill.
Hard to muster up against the Morganas.
Oui, but they started it.
@BATTLE
Looks like it's time to finish it.
Once again.
Just the person I wanted to see. Spot for me, won't you?
Cutting down our finned friend?
Just his jaw. I'll need a bigger fire for this one.
No longer, Capitaine. If we leave this exposed to the elements, it will be devoured by scavengers. The last thing we want to do is offend Missinak.
Missinak?
One of the utshimau, the animal masters. He rules over the creatures of the seas and rivers.

Fields.MenuText: And he's okay with you killing them?
What's he think about the Morganas?
You'd think he'd help us out more.

Fields.DialogueText: If I do it respectfully.
They are not his. That's all I know.
I would not. He's got problems of his own.
So the fishing's not going to be great if we don't get this right. I think I can live with that.
Do not tempt fate, Capitaine. Least of all in an apocalypse.
I'm not the one up there.
Doing some scouting?
Can it wait? We're in Morgana waters.
You couldn't handle it. I... oh, sacrament. Manitou.
At least you don't have to climb down.
But I do have to secure this thing. And pray like hell that it survives the battle.
@BATTLE
Is that so strange?
Well, you're Catholic... ish. I know you believe in God.
I believe in many spirits. I don't believe in playing téléphone sans fil when I can talk to them myself.
And anyway, the Pope can deal with it. That idiotic treaty he signed with the Germans is proof enough that...

Fields.MenuText: I thought you could use a break. You've been so high-strung lately.
Let them work. They volunteered when I floated the idea.
Don't you trust the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: A bow doesn't fire any other way!
They don't understand the forces they're dealing with!
They are learning, Capitaine, but they are not prepared to handle this!
We dined like kings on shark meat. You can't blame them for wanting to help.
Non, Capitaine, I can blame you later. Sailor! Give me that rope at once!
Fine. We'll take over, but I-
Stay back! One slip and this whole thing could-
-Break?
So you've never been to confession?
Oh, yes, I was going to tell you about the shark.
... Capitaine. What do the crew think they're doing?
They'll ruin it! We have to stop them at once!
Grr... and Manitou are coming to laugh at us. You and I will deal with this later.
@BATTLE
What did we manage to salvage?
Assorted vertebrae and ribs... the entire tail, somehow... and fully half of the lower jaw. Bien.
So we're all right?
We most certainly are not all right!

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes it's difficult to tell when you're being sarcastic.
It was an honest mistake.
What about the rest of it?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, just watch my antlers. They wiggle when they detect irony.
For the sailors, oui. You and I are complicit in a terrible breach of etiquette.
Dust, or washed overboard.
So what do we do now?
We make amends, to the extent that this is possible. The first order of business is to burn this jawbone.
... Really?
Pantoute.
Cartilage.
What?
Sharks have cartilaginous skeletons. Is that going to-
I'll give you a cartilaginous skeleton.
What does that even mean?
Whatever I decide it to mean! Help me scare these Morganas away from the mess we've made.
@BATTLE
All right, stand back. It took me all morning to set this up.
Standing back.
I still can't believe this jaw broke almost exactly in half.
Can we still get something out of it?
Of course. It won't be what we want, though.

Fields.MenuText: That's life.
We'll get half the story?
We're not doomed, are we?

Fields.DialogueText: True enough. We've got to deal with the unexpected... and atone for our transgressions along the way.
You're lucky you're good-looking.
Far from it, Capitaine, but we will be sorely inconvenienced.
Let me see if I understand. We handled the skeleton... indelicately.
Carelessly, even.
Fair.
Maybe it's my fault after all.
Saguenay?
When you helped me with the shark... when you killed it... you assumed partial responsibility for it. As a hunter you're charged with disposing of its body properly.
I'm sorry, Capitaine. I should never have gotten you involved in this.
Wait, Saguenay-
Here come some Manitou. I'll move the jaw somewhere safe.
@BATTLE
You've got quite the fire going. You're not too warm?
We may be in the tropics right now, but the smell of smoke keeps my focus sharp.
It was considerate of you to keep it downwind of the rest of the ship.
Merci, Capitaine. I refuse to make my crew uncomfortable.

Fields.MenuText: What about your captain?
Aren't you the one who forbade whistling?
They're in the wrong line of work if they can't deal with a little smoke.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like a personal problem.
They will thank me for every storm that doesn't blow them overboard.
It could be worse. Surcouf-sis is a submarine. A chain-smoking submarine... tabarnak.
Looks like it's just about done cooking.
Let's see. Hmm...
Odd. I've never seen a marking like this before.
Looks like... a candy wrapper?
Don't be dense. The lines cross at one end... run parallel... and then cross at the other. Losing something only to regain it?
Almost like tea leaves.
That reminds me... you owe me a reading.
Careful what you wish for. I might accidentally drop the pot and break it.
Torrieu. Your track record makes me reluctant to argue.
My track record of victory against the Morganas?
Honestly, are we going to spend this entire war shoring up your ego?
@BATTLE
Reading our fortune in the stars?
Ugh. Never. Astrology may be the one superstition I do not understand.
Whistling and bananas scare you, and astrology is your limit?
It's ludicrous on its face. There is no ritual in it, no practice, no logic. You're born under certain signs and that's who you are. So thought-terminating.

Fields.MenuText: Spoken like a true Gemini.
I think anyone can become what they really want to be.
Aren't Belles... kind of that way?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm going to take your word for it.
Why let the heavens define you?
We're real, Capitaine. There's a difference.
I got rid of the rest of the shark as you asked.
Exactly as I asked?
To the letter. It belongs to the sea again.
Thank goodness. Maybe now she'll hear me.
Who'll hear you?
Did I not tell you about my great-grandmother?
Belles can have those?
We have sisters. Why not ancestors?
I see. Was she not listening before?
When my spirit wandered in dreams... I could hear her. It was unclear, as if I were listening to a sister that had not yet awakened.
But her spirit was the same as mine. And when I woke up, I would often find that she'd guided me to something I hadn't noticed before.
But you couldn't talk back.
What spirits do is their business. But, well...
It'd be nice to say hello to family.
It would at that. Hmm... I'll need to do some thinking.
Let's do some fighting first. I think I see Morganas headed this way...
@BATTLE
Good morning, Captain! Good morning, Saguenay! It's good to see the happy couple back together!
Couple? Do people think we're a couple?
We do spend a lot of time in each other's company.
You are my capitaine. It would be odd if we didn't.
And I suppose the fresh-made tea and bacon each morning is part of a Belle's duties.
... It should be.

Fields.MenuText: Is there something you'd like to talk about?
The notion of superpowered battle maids is an appealing one.
Well, I appreciate it. It really wakes me up in the morning.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. And no.
Don't make it weird, Capitaine.
Bien. I'm glad.
I'm conflicted.
You? Conflicted? What happened to knowing everything?
There were other signs in the shark jaw. A broken arrow... a burning canoe...
What does it mean?
What I feared it meant when we angered Missinak. This period of relative quiet is the calm before a very difficult storm.
Whatever you need me to do, I'll be there for you.
That's just it, Capitaine... You have done your part disposing of the skeleton. Now I must do mine.
... Alone.
You're sure?
I would not expose you to the wrath of the utshimau. You don't know how to deal with them. I do.
All the more reason to teach me!
When you're ahead, minimize risk. We've fared well so far against the Manitou. I will not see our advantage squandered.
Steady on, then. Here come some more.
@BATTLE
What's the news from Command?
Grim.
Better than dire.
Those maelstroms aren't getting any smaller. And every day you hear about some fishing village or island community vanishing off the map.
A Belle's work is never done.
Nor a captain's. How's nature holding up?
Grim.

Fields.MenuText: Bad fishing?
Missinak still cross with you?
So we don't have seafood for a while. Big deal.

Fields.DialogueText: No fishing.
It's getting better.
If only it were simple luxury at stake.
Think of it like a system of social credit. Goodwill is much easier to erase than offense, and takes longer to reestablish.
So getting the animals to come back is... it's sort of like penance.
In the most superficial of ways, I suppose it is. But if I have to choose between a Hail Mary and a successful hunt, I know which will get me through a hard winter.
Is this your roundabout way of saying nothing's biting?
It's not like I'm shifting the blame.
Maybe if I-
Non. This is my problem to fix.
But the Manitou are ours. Let's get to the bridge.
@BATTLE
Can't sleep?
Won't sleep. Not for rest, anyway.
You only dream when you think you'll see something?

Fields.MenuText: Just for fun. Your mind does strange things when you're not looking.
What if your spirits want to talk to you?
For the same reason you pray?

Fields.DialogueText: I prefer to be in control of my faculties, thank you.
They have other ways of communicating with me. I am always listening.
Prayer is asking for the scales to be tipped. Everything else is determining how they are weighted.
You seem remarkably sure of yourself.
I am always sure of myself. Indecision is death out here.
So is eating bananas, apparently.
I know you didn't come out here to ridicule me.
I didn't. But you're clearly troubled. You've been taciturn lately.
Have you met me?
Come on. What is it?
If I tell you, you'll want to help.
What's wrong with that?
I'll be tempted to say yes.
When I need clarity. Why else would I dream?
Minimize risk, eh?
It's nothing personal.
Somehow I'm not so sure.
Get to the bridge before these Morganas enter firing range or I'll drag you there myself.
See? That was personal.
@BATTLE
Any luck fishing?
Not since last you asked.
Maybe we're not looking hard enough.
Capitaine, what are you doing?
I finished up the after action report a little early this time around. There's only so many ways I can tell Command we won.
Well, you can sit there all you want. It won't attract any fish.
One way to find out.
Well, whether or not you catch anything... thank you for stopping by out here.

Fields.MenuText: I've been worried about you. You've been distant.
I probably won't be out here too long. I know you get particular.
It's nice to spend time with you when we're not fighting for our lives.

Fields.DialogueText: A safe distance.
Stay as long as you like, Capitaine. I find it's good for the soul.
A reminder of what we're fighting for is necessary now and again.
Hear anything from your great-grandmother?
Lately... non. She's been absent from my dreams.
So what have you been dreaming about?
... Vikings.
Wish I could have some of those dreams.
Non, Capitaine, I... Do you remember this valknut?
The trefoil thing, yeah. That's got to be the oldest manmade thing I've ever seen. What does it mean, again?
I'm not certain. It's religious in nature, probably, but which god or giant it honors, which blessing it asks for... it's impossible to determine.
So I choose to believe all possibilities are true.
Isn't that cheating?
If I honor them equally, why would it be? I acknowledge my own ignorance and choose respect as my default.
I feel like you're trying to tell me something.
If anything... please understand that I do not exclude you from my rituals for personal reasons. Sometimes it's best to keep to one's own things and let others function as they must.
I guess I can't argue with that. We can still fish, though.
... I can cook it for you if you handle the rest. Not as if either of us is going to-
Whoa! It's a big one!
Franchement? ... Marde, I see Manitou coming this way. Give the line to me, Capitaine. I'll pull it in faster.
@BATTLE
Have you noticed how alone we are lately, Capitaine?
About a hundred and eighty sailors would disagree.
That's not what I mean. Look around. Have you seen any living animals in the past several days?

Fields.MenuText: I thought the sky seemed a little too clear.
The fishing's been a bit sparse lately.
Not a moose to be found.

Fields.DialogueText: Birds never fly toward Manitou if they can help it. I can't even make a rough estimate based on that now.
We even spread out to cover more ground. Water, rather.
One of these days I'm going to lock you in a room with one.
I caught that big fish just the other day.
It's the only one we've seen in weeks. I don't like this, Capitaine.
I never took you for the jealous type.
The day I have to be jealous of you is the day you sweep me off my feet in single combat.
Is that a challenge?
An assessment. Would you like it to be a challenge?
Oh, I don't know if it would be sporting. You did get disarmed by a shark, after all.
... You. Me. Knives.
Uh... oh, damn, wouldn't you know it? Morganas.
Don't think you'll get out of it this easily...
@BATTLE
I think I've solved our little animal problem.
I know you haven't.
Hear me out. You use scapulimancy to fill in the holes in our intel, and that's not available right now. Why not another method of divination?
I could certainly use a cup of tea. But I strongly doubt I'll learn from it.
Why's that?
Do you know what to look for, Capitaine?
I know to look. We can discuss the meaning once we settle on shapes.
... Very well. Still got that tea doll I made you?

Fields.MenuText: Straight. Nothing interfering with the flavor.
Spoonful of honey.
Milk and sugar to the top.

Fields.DialogueText: The correct answer.
Not unheard of.
... If you say so.
Just what I needed. All right, let's see what we've got in our cups.
For just such an occasion. My quarters?
Of course. Let's see if we can clear the seas a bit first.
@BATTLE
How do you take your tea, Capitaine?
I see... this looks like a bird. Ironic.
Funny. I'm seeing one in yours as well. Next to... a heart?
Hmm... Capitaine, are you sure you didn't rig these cups?
How the hell would I do that? More to the point, why?
Because it's something I would do if I thought it might work.
Looking for romance and birds?
I - well, not specifically, but - you have to look at what the things represent. The birds indicate that my relationship with the animal masters must be repaired.
And the hearts?
Decision. Resolution. The way you stabbed the shark in the heart is how I should approach my problems. Educated guesses.
Pardon, Capitaine, I think I... left a tea doll out in... in the elements. Oui.
More tea for me, then...
I never got a chance to thank you properly for the tea.
Désolée, Capitaine. I had pressing business above.
Don't worry about it. Wouldn't want to waste a tea doll.
Tea doll?
The one you left out.
Ah! Oui, of course. That one.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure there's not something you want to talk about?
I'm glad you caught that. It'd be a shame to see good tea go to waste.
All right, out with it. What's on your mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, I... well, non.
True enough, Capitaine, but... oh, this is silly.
It's improper.
I've been trying to figure something out. Something about you.
Wait, really? What about me?
I dreamed of my great-grandmother last night.
Saguenay, that's great! What did she say?
She showed me a river and we fished for a night. "We" being us.
So is suffering in silence. What's going on?
As in you and me?
It made me think of the last fish either of us caught.
Ha! Yeah, that was a pretty big one I landed. I guess you were my lucky charm.
You're actually not far off the mark. I wonder if it's not the other way round.
... Wait, you mean me? Saguenay, what's this even about? Doesn't this mean the spirits are okay with us after all?
There's that "us" again. I... grr. Manitou.
Let's deal with the immediate problem first.
@BATTLE
Arrêtez là! Capitaine, stay there.
Saguenay, what's the matter? I was just coming up for some fresh- whoa!
Capitaine! Not one more step until I have cleansed the deck.
Where did all these birds come from? I haven't seen them since-
Since we shattered that shark's jaw? This is what I was talking about, Capitaine. The calm before the storm... and you caught in it.
Wait. Stop. This was all about me?
Wait, let me explain...

Fields.MenuText: How do you really feel?
It'll take more than some dead birds to stop us.
Explain. Tell me what happened.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Angry.
It's not the birds. It's what they represent.
Brace yourself, Capitaine.
It happened while you were busy writing. First one slammed into the deck... then another... and before I knew it, an entire flock of seabirds had just... well, look here.
Does it matter? Whatever this is, I can put a stop to it without risking you.
And how is this different from the Morganas?
It's supernatural. Supernatural problems require supernatural solutions.
Why?
So the Morganas aren't supernatural?
... You're tenacious. Perceptive. It's one of many things I admire about you.
What a moment this is, eh? You, me, and a hundred dead birds.
And a passel of Manitou. You know my speed. Deal with them while I clean up these birds.
@BATTLE
Fishing again?
I brought an extra rod. I'm trying to test something.
I never say no to spending some time with you.
I'm glad you feel that way, Capitaine... that has been on my mind quite a lot lately.

Fields.MenuText: We make a good team.
Whatever makes fishing more bearable.
Do you ever think about what we'll do after the war?

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. But I have been struggling with what that means.
There is serenity in it even without a catch. It reminds one of their place in their world.
Go back to cooler waters, for a start. My hull is meant for ice and snowmelt... not this tropical stew.
The Manitou are yours to contend with, and mine. When we desecrated the shark and disrupted the hunts... that unleashed something else.
I feel fine, for what it's worth.
And that is a comfort to my soul. But Capitaine, I feel I have not been honest with you.
I like you too.
Oui, I am afraid- quoi?
You're a terror in a fight. But you've got this astonishing gentleness when it comes to the world you fight for. That fascinates me. You fascinate me.
I... I was afraid you'd say this, Capitaine.
Afraid?
Because I wanted to say it first. Ease you into my world, until you were ready to... meet the family, as it were.
And then you caught that shark.
You landed it.
You pulled it aboard.
You killed it.
Seems a certain Missinak likes playing matchmaker.
The animal masters have been known to dabble in human affairs when it amused them. Perhaps they figured we were stronger together than apart.
So what about the birds?
Manitou trickery, then. None of the utshimau would spend the lives of their followers so crassly.
Damn. Looks like we can ask them ours- ah, hell! Saguenay, I've got a bite!
Then we are on the right track. Make ready!
@BATTLE
Capitaine... that's it!
What's it?
I've hit upon a suitable answer to the challenge of Missinak.

Fields.MenuText: A kiss isn't enough?
Another shark?
The birds?

Fields.DialogueText: It's certainly welcome. But there is a better demonstration of our commitment.
Nothing so grand, Capitaine. Or at least nothing so large.
The birds.
Remember the valknut, Capitaine?
How could I forget? It's probably the oldest thing on the ship.
It gave me an idea. Some way to remand them to Missinak's embrace while turning the Manitou's evil back upon them.
Aren't we moving a bit quickly?
Behave, Capitaine.
A Viking funeral.
You speak my very thoughts.
I happen to appreciate pyrotechnics. Especially respectful, restorative pyrotechnics.
Consider it our first step together into my world.
Superstitions were one thing, Saguenay... I'm still going to need time for your spirits.
Are they such an unbelievable thing to share the world with? You have Belles, after all. You have me.
I wouldn't pick any other guide.
Nor I any other companion. We'll need a lifeboat for our inaugural explosion, of course.
Approved. It's a sacrifice we can afford to make.
Was that your attempt at a pun?
Hopefully the Morganas heard it. It may yet do some good.
@BATTLE
You don't happen to have any spare furs, do you, Capitaine?
Is that a rhetorical question?
An optimistic one. Ah, well. Cotton will do.
What's the project?
Before I answer that question... I must come clean. I did not get the chance to be honest with you earlier.

Fields.MenuText: You need to double confess?
There's a gorgeous seaplane tender. I knew it!
You're the most honest person I know.

Fields.DialogueText: Not exactly.
I'm trying to bare my soul, Capitaine.
This is one way you know I have mastered camouflage.
Ever since the shark... catching it... I have seen in you the potential to help me. I need another to help contact my great-grandmother.
Who is she, exactly?
An S-class from the days of the Great War. You know her as HMS Somme. She was broken up a year after I was born.
Before you even awakened. I'm sorry.
Death is not so final as you would think, Capitaine. We merely move on to another world... a parallel world, or one beyond, if you choose Heaven. I know Great-grandma Somme chose the former.
Because you can hear her. What's that got to do with me?
The bond we have developed... our prowess as a team... I saw in you the aid I needed. I allowed the shark incident to shake my faith, and for that I am sorry.
Well, if we're both sorry, eliminate common factors and we're back where we started.
Ugh. Math. And yet how refreshingly simple.
It was not merely your safety I feared for... it was my connection with Somme.
I know how much your only family means to you, Saguenay. Of course I'll help you contact her.
So what does the cloth have to do with it?
Manitou first. Religion lesson after.
@BATTLE
My lifeboat? You know my specifications. It's big enough to hold seabirds and thermite.
Doesn't an occasion like this call for something... grander?
Are you saying I am not grand?

Fields.MenuText: A veritable dinghy.
Keeping my on my toes, aren't you?
Not at all.

Fields.DialogueText: Spoken like a true ensign.
Better me than some other predator.
The look on your face, Capitaine... you are too sweet for your own good.
Only one thing is missing, of course, and that is the fire.
That's where you come in.
Your lighter, Capitaine.
You're quite a shot with that bow.
Merci. It is... how did you put it... highly strung?
I wouldn't have it any other way.
And that's one Manitou out of the fight before it even starts. As worthy a sendoff for Missinak's creatures if ever I saw one.
@BATTLE
Somehow it's smaller than I expected.
Bon. Fire for effect.
Granted.
All right, tell me how this works.
It's quite simple. You assist as I build the tent. Then watch as I enter and communne with a mishtapeu.
Bless you.
Don't be crass, Capitaine. I'm talking about one of the spirits that lives in the parallel world, Tshishtashkamuk.

Fields.MenuText: I swear you're making these up.
Good or evil?
Is it... safe?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be rude. The rest of the world pronounces "Roosevelt" just fine.
Good, generally. It's the meminiteu you have to watch out for.
Completely safe for you. And you need not worry about me.
All right, this looks like a tent.
And these look like Manitou. This stays standing.
@BATTLE
All right, everything's in place. What do I do?
Stand there and look pretty. And whatever you hear or see, do not interfere. This is between me and the mishtapeu.
Saguenay... whoa!
I'm fine, Capitaine. This is called the shaking tent ceremony for a reason.
One can only attune to a single mishtapeu. But if I don't get it right... well, it'll be all right. At least I'll know. Now, then...
You really think this spirit will get you in contact with Somme?
Join me in some stargazing?
J'adorerais. What a great night for it, too. Look at all the stars...
It is quite beautiful. Shame the Morganas don't appreciate it.
No matter what our world endures, the stars shine on. Magnifique. What's your favorite part about the night?

Fields.MenuText: I'm usually never awake this late. Early to bed, early to rise.
I love the stars, too. Who knows what's beyond what we can see?
I love the darkness. It turns every night into a different mystery.

Fields.DialogueText: Beware of routine, Capitaine.
It is an interesting question. But there is more than enough here on this world to challenge me.
Obstacles... predators... prey... all so much more thrilling on a hunt in the dark.
I just can't get over how chilly it is.
I am a little bit cold. Is there any way you could get a little closer to me?
Don't you enjoy the cold?
I think, Capitaine, I have reached a new understanding with the temperature.
What's that?
A hunter who lets a little heat get to her head is in need of practice. Though I admit you have a way of getting to mine.
Practice makes perfect.
Mmm.
So what did you hear in the tent?
Roaring winds, at first. Animal cries from a thousand forests... some familiar, some foreign. But through it all there was... a voice. New, yet greeting me like an old friend.
Your mishtapeu?
My mishtapeu.
And what did it say?
Let's teach them some respect, shall we?
@BATTLE
"I knew we'd find each other. Now, how fares the Empire?"
Have you ever seen so many birds before?
And following us north, too. Missinak blesses our journey home.
I'll take his help. The Morganas aren't letting us back into cooler waters without a fight.
@BATTLE
There's still a score to settle, Capitaine.
I thought we'd tied everything up quite neatly.
Presque. There is still the matter of the challenge you issued me.

Fields.MenuText: You know I was just joking about your knife, right?
I don't remember challenging you to anything.
Ready to lose, then?

Fields.DialogueText: It takes two to joke, and I was not joking.
Then you will learn not to issue them so lightly.
Always, Capitaine. One must prepare even for the impossible.
Hardly seems fair. You've got your ancestor whispering over your shoulder...
A house you helped build, Capitaine. Literally. And you without a shark to disarm me...
I'll have to manage somehow. Now, what was that about sweeping you off your feet?
They do not appreciate a Newfoundland chill as I do. The battle is won already.
You are welcome to try... as many times as it takes.
